        Hello,<span class="line"><!---->Hello,<!----></span><br>Good afternoon. <span class="line"><!---->Good afternoon. <!----></span><br>RE <span class="line"><!---->RE <!----></span>comment#48<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c48"><!---->comment#48<!----></a>: Thank you @amy ma'am. :)<span class="line"><!---->: Thank you @amy ma'am. :)<!----></span><br><br>I am currently not sure about this. But @knollr is it possible to check this case as well? We've got one more URI like `tel:` which is `callto:`. I was trying to go more deeper for the `tel:` URI in the RFC5341 at [1]. While going through that, something which clicked to me was about Skype which also has ability to call and as Skype uses URI like `callto:`, if we use that URI with the USSD code, it will directly be called, PTAL at [2]. Currently, I haven't tried to check if this will be possible to use. Like if we use USSD code and if the user has selected Skype as application which should be used then it might be problem. <span class="line"><!---->I am currently not sure about this. But @knollr is it possible to check this case as well? We've got one more URI like `tel:` which is `callto:`. I was trying to go more deeper for the `tel:` URI in the RFC5341 at [1]. While going through that, something which clicked to me was about Skype which also has ability to call and as Skype uses URI like `callto:`, if we use that URI with the USSD code, it will directly be called, PTAL at [2]. Currently, I haven't tried to check if this will be possible to use. Like if we use USSD code and if the user has selected Skype as application which should be used then it might be problem. <!----></span><br><br>And is it really possible to use phone number without prefix `tel:`? Maybe check [3].<span class="line"><!---->And is it really possible to use phone number without prefix `tel:`? Maybe check [3].<!----></span><br><br>Viber also has a URI  like `viber://` it also has calling function but have never seen a real life example where it will be possible to make a call. Like for whatsapp too we have ability to send a text and that too the test will be added in the text box but won't be sent until user clicks `>`/Send. So, yes, application like this who have calling function won't be affected from it and as Chrome would be stripping it out on their behalf for `tel:` URI, there won't be issue.<span class="line"><!---->Viber also has a URI  like `viber://` it also has calling function but have never seen a real life example where it will be possible to make a call. Like for whatsapp too we have ability to send a text and that too the test will be added in the text box but won't be sent until user clicks `&gt;`/Send. So, yes, application like this who have calling function won't be affected from it and as Chrome would be stripping it out on their behalf for `tel:` URI, there won't be issue.<!----></span><br><br>Will `callto:` have similar issue? The protection is well implemented by the team for `tel:` URI as the `%` itself is blocked so, everything is in good hands and there is no bypass. :P But would be happy if one can check for this `callto:` functionality. Does this work? I don't have skype on my device but maybe try with this:<span class="line"><!---->Will `callto:` have similar issue? The protection is well implemented by the team for `tel:` URI as the `%` itself is blocked so, everything is in good hands and there is no bypass. :P But would be happy if one can check for this `callto:` functionality. Does this work? I don't have skype on my device but maybe try with this:<!----></span><br><br>data:text/html,<a href="callto:*%2306%23">click</a><span class="line"><!---->data:text/html,&lt;a href="callto:*%2306%23"&gt;click&lt;/a&gt;<!----></span><br><br>When I use that URI in the Chrome stable (OS: Android), it says about:blank#blocked, looks like to be good but no idea why it has different behavior in the Desktop. I don't have one iOS device on my hand. So, I don't know what is behavior on it. But most probably iOS will have same behavior as Android.<span class="line"><!---->When I use that URI in the Chrome stable (OS: Android), it says about:blank#blocked, looks like to be good but no idea why it has different behavior in the Desktop. I don't have one iOS device on my hand. So, I don't know what is behavior on it. But most probably iOS will have same behavior as Android.<!----></span><br><br><br>[1]: <span class="line"><!---->[1]: <!----></span>https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc5341<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc5341"><!---->https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc5341<!----></a><br>[2]: <span class="line"><!---->[2]: <!----></span>https://stackoverflow.com/questions/20132663/sending-ussd-code-programmatically-dials-skype-instead-of-normal-phone-call<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/20132663/sending-ussd-code-programmatically-dials-skype-instead-of-normal-phone-call"><!---->https://stackoverflow.com/questions/20132663/sending-ussd-code-programmatically-dials-skype-instead-of-normal-phone-call<!----></a><br>[3]: <span class="line"><!---->[3]: <!----></span>https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Property:P1329<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Property:P1329"><!---->https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Property:P1329<!----></a><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Click to Call (the feature that sends a number from desktop > phone) is only shown for tel: links [1] and won't show for callto: or other external protocols.<span class="line"><!---->Click to Call (the feature that sends a number from desktop &gt; phone) is only shown for tel: links [1] and won't show for callto: or other external protocols.<!----></span><br>If you find an issue with those links (callto, viber, etc) feel free to open a new bug with the repro steps but it'll likely not affect Click to Call.<span class="line"><!---->If you find an issue with those links (callto, viber, etc) feel free to open a new bug with the repro steps but it'll likely not affect Click to Call.<!----></span><br><br>[1]: <span class="line"><!---->[1]: <!----></span>https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:chrome/browser/sharing/click_to_call/click_to_call_utils.cc;l=82;drc=9fcc9d7b2915b6192ee6810eec54c50deb6313c6<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:chrome/browser/sharing/click_to_call/click_to_call_utils.cc;l=82;drc=9fcc9d7b2915b6192ee6810eec54c50deb6313c6"><!---->https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:chrome/browser/sharing/click_to_call/click_to_call_utils.cc;l=82;drc=9fcc9d7b2915b6192ee6810eec54c50deb6313c6<!----></a><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>

          Comment 53<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1180510#c53">Comment 53<!----></a>

public once a fix has been widely<!----></b><br>deployed.<b class="line"><!---->deployed.<!----></b><br><br>-------------------------<b issue.<b class="line"><!---->Please provide a brief explanation of the security issue.<!----></b><br><br>VERSION<b class="line"><!---->VERSION<!----></b><br>Chrome Version: 88.0.4324.150 (Official include a demonstration of the security bug, such as an attached<b class="line"><!---->Please include a demonstration of the security bug, such as an attached<!----></b><br>HTML or binary file that reproduces the bug when loaded in Chrome. PLEASE<!----></b><br>make the file as small as possible and remove any content not required to<b class="line"><!---->make the file as small as possible and remove any content not required to<!----></b><br>demonstrate the bug, or any personal or confidential information.<b class="line"><!---->demonstrate the bug, or any personal or confidential information.<!----></b><br><br>Please attach files directly, not in zip or other archive formats, and if<b class="line"><!---->Please attach files directly, not in zip or other archive formats, and if<!----></b><br>you've created a demonstration site please also attach the files needed to<b class="line"><!---->you've created a demonstration site please also attach the files needed to<!----></b><br>reproduce the demonstration locally.<b class="line"><!---->reproduce the demonstration locally.<!----></b><br><br>FOR CRASHES, PLEASE INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING ADDITIONAL INFORMATION<b class="line"><!---->FOR CRASHES, PLEASE INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING ADDITIONAL INFORMATION<!----></b><br>Type of crash: [tab, browser, etc.]<b class="line"><!---->Type of crash: [tab, browser, etc.]<!----></b><br>Crash State: [see link above: stack trace *with symbols*, registers,<b class="line"><!---->Crash State: [see link above: stack trace *with symbols*, registers,<!----></b><br>exception record]<b class="line"><!---->exception record]<!----></b><br>Client ID (if relevant): [see link above]<b class="line"><!---->Client ID (if relevant): [see link above]<!----></b><br><br>CREDIT INFORMATION<b class="line"><!---->CREDIT INFORMATION<!----></b><br>Externally reported security bugs may appear in Chrome release notes.         Respected Sir/Ma'am,<span class="line"><!---->Respected Sir/Ma'am,<!----></span><br><br>Good evening. Hope you're doing well. Okay, yes, let's talk about the issue. I will bisect the report into few parts for better understanding.<span class="line"><!---->Good evening. Hope you're doing well. Okay, yes, let's talk about the issue. I will bisect the report into few parts for better understanding.<!----></span><br><br>1. As far as I know, browsers have a security implementation that one can't use "tel:" in the iframes means it won't open Phone Dialer app. Let's see a proof?<span class="line"><!---->1. As far as I know, browsers have a security implementation that one can't use "tel:" in the iframes means it won't open Phone Dialer app. Let's see a proof?<!----></span><br>--> Enter this into the address bar: data:text/html,<iframe src='tel:+91123456789'><span class="line"><!---->--&gt; Enter this into the address bar: data:text/html,&lt;iframe src='tel:+91123456789'&gt;<!----></span><br>Observations on 2 different Operating Systems:<span class="line"><!---->Observations on 2 different Operating Systems:<!----></span><br><br>Chrome Android (Dev | Version: 90.0.4413.0 | Android 9.0): It doesn't open Dialer app in the Android Browser.<span class="line"><!---->Chrome Android (Dev | Version: 90.0.4413.0 | Android 9.0): It doesn't open Dialer app in the Android Browser.<!----></span><br>Reason: I am not sure for the reason but it maybe because the one can't open applications from iframe using URIs like tel: mailto: etc?<span class="line"><!---->Reason: I am not sure for the reason but it maybe because the one can't open applications from iframe using URIs like tel: mailto: etc?<!----></span><br><br>Chrome Windows (Stable | Version: 88.0.4324.150 | Windows 10 x64): It will give a prompt like something where you can select a device where the same Gmail is logged in as Chrome (desktop) and once you'll click it, it will open the Dialer Android App. <span class="line"><!---->Chrome Windows (Stable | Version: 88.0.4324.150 | Windows 10 x64): It will give a prompt like something where you can select a device where the same Gmail is logged in as Chrome (desktop) and once you'll click it, it will open the Dialer Android App. <!----></span><br>Reason: The Browser allowed tel URI from iframe which shouldn't be allowed.<span class="line"><!---->Reason: The Browser allowed tel URI from iframe which shouldn't be allowed.<!----></span><br><br>Let's go to next step. As per @rbyers. there can be issues like Factory data reset etc can take place in some Android devices. I have kept a PoC where there is tel: with a '*' in it and it wasn't stripped out by the Browser when sent to the Dialer app of Android device. <span class="line"><!---->Let's go to next step. As per @rbyers. there can be issues like Factory data reset etc can take place in some Android devices. I have kept a PoC where there is tel: with a '*' in it and it wasn't stripped out by the Browser when sent to the Dialer app of Android device. <!----></span><br><br>2. Few Browsers who are Chromium based aren't checking the characters after '*' and completely transferred the USSD code to the Dialer Application which maybe a huge concern for them. What kind of security check Chrome has implemented to protect against such issues, can you please share a link to that specific security check or feature? Thanks in advance. :) <span class="line"><!---->2. Few Browsers who are Chromium based aren't checking the characters after '*' and completely transferred the USSD code to the Dialer Application which maybe a huge concern for them. What kind of security check Chrome has implemented to protect against such issues, can you please share a link to that specific security check or feature? Thanks in advance. :) <!----></span><br><br>I will conclude here and tell that Chrome (desktop) is allowing tel: in the Iframe which shouldn't be done and which can be a huge security concern in older Android devices. I am not sure but this is also an issue in the Android device when it takes any digits on the dialer app without checking? If it is, what kind of check do Android OS have to protect users from it? I am always eager to learn something new from Chromium Security Team as they have got one of the best Browser team all over the World. Thanks in advance. Take care!<span class="line"><!---->I will conclude here and tell that Chrome (desktop) is allowing tel: in the Iframe which shouldn't be done and which can be a huge security concern in older Android devices. I am not sure but this is also an issue in the Android device when it takes any digits on the dialer app without checking? If it is, what kind of check do Android OS have to protect users from it? I am always eager to learn something new from Chromium Security Team as they have got one of the best Browser team all over the World. Thanks in advance.         Thanks for your report. I think what you're saying is that there are two possible bugs that intertwine interestingly:<span class="line"><!---->Thanks for your report. I think what you're saying is that there are two possible bugs that intertwine interestingly:<!----></span><br> 1. Desktop users can click a tel: link in an iframe. On Chrome, you can then send that number to a mobile Chrome, which then passes it to the dialer.<span class="line"><!----> 1. Desktop users can click a tel: link in an iframe. On Chrome, you can then send that number to a mobile Chrome, which then passes it to the dialer.<!----></span><br> 2. Since Chrome doesn't strip # and * from the number, someone could do something nefarious.<span class="line"><!----> 2. Since Chrome doesn't strip # and * from the number, someone could do something nefarious.<!----></span><br><br>As you noted, the second one is a known issue (<span class="line"><!---->As you noted, the second one is a known issue (<!----></span>crbug.com/746427<a class="" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=746427" title="Are some tel: links a security issue on Android?"><!---->crbug.com/746427<!----></a>). I don't know whether the lack of iframe tel support on Android is intentional or not, but it does seem plausible that we should share the behavior.<span class="line"><!---->). I don't know whether the lack of iframe tel support on Android is intentional or not, but it does seem plausible that we should share the behavior.<!----></span><br><br>mkwst@/qinmin@: do you know if the iframe tel mitigation is intentional and/or based on some spec? Ought the desktop/Android behavior be unified?<span class="line"><!---->mkwst@/qinmin@: do you know if the iframe tel mitigation is intentional and/or based on some spec? Ought the desktop/Android behavior be unified?<!----></span><br><br>I'm keeping this as a security bug for now, albeit Severity-Low, out of an abundance of caution. Fixing the iframe limitation would only be a fairly minimal abuse mitigation for the <span class="line"><!---->I'm keeping this as a security bug for now, albeit Severity-Low, out of an abundance of caution. Fixing the iframe limitation would only be a fairly minimal abuse mitigation for the <!----></span>crbug.com/746427<a class="" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=746427" title="Are some tel: links a security issue on Android?"><!---->crbug.com/746427<!----></a> issue, but whether or not unadorned iframes should have that privilege still seems like an OWP security question.<span class="line"><!----> issue, but whether or not unadorned iframes should have that privilege still seems like an OWP security question.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        The relevant specs are quite vague on navigation to non-webby schemes. The switch in step 15 of <span class="line"><!---->The relevant specs are quite vague on navigation to non-webby schemes. The switch in step 15 of <!----></span>https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/browsing-the-web.html#navigate<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/browsing-the-web.html#navigate"><!---->https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/browsing-the-web.html#navigate<!----></a> takes you to <span class="line"><!----> takes you to <!----></span>https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/browsing-the-web.html#process-a-navigate-url-scheme<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/browsing-the-web.html#process-a-navigate-url-scheme"><!---->https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/browsing-the-web.html#process-a-navigate-url-scheme<!----></a>,<span class="line"><!---->,<!----></span> and then to <span class="line"><!----> and then to <!----></span>https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/browsing-the-web.html#hand-off-to-external-software<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/browsing-the-web.html#hand-off-to-external-software"><!---->https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/browsing-the-web.html#hand-off-to-external-software<!----></a>,<span class="line"><!---->,<!----></span> which waves its hands in the direction of a risk to be mitigated, but has little concrete advice about doing so.<span class="line"><!----> which waves its hands in the direction of a risk to be mitigated, but has little concrete advice about doing so.<!----></span><br><br>I don't know of an intentional handling of `tel` for framed navigation, but I agree that we should be consistent across desktop and mobile. Skimming through the codebase for instances of `kTelScheme`, we have a few features which special-case it in some way (<span class="line"><!---->I don't know of an intentional handling of `tel` for framed navigation, but I agree that we should be consistent across desktop and mobile.         A few observations here :-)<span class="line"><!---->A few observations here :-)<!----></span><br>On Android we do seem to block navigations to external protocols here [1]. They fail with a "Navigation is blocked: tel:+xxx" log message in the JS console.<span class="line"><!---->On Android we do seem to block navigations to external protocols here [1]. They fail with a "Navigation is blocked: tel:+xxx" log message in the JS console.<!----></span><br>That doesn't prevent the user from clicking on tel: links though, even if the link itself is in an iframe. Relevant bug: <span class="line"><!---->That doesn't prevent the user from clicking on tel: links though, even if the link itself is in an iframe. Relevant bug: <!----></span>crbug.com/594996<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://crbug.com/594996"><!---->crbug.com/594996<!----></a><br>For desktop there is an open bug to limit external protocol navigations here: <span class="line"><!---->For desktop there is an open bug to limit external protocol navigations here: <!----></span>crbug.com/1011429<a class="" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1011429" title="Add metrics for deprecating non-understandable external protocol requests"><!---->crbug.com/1011429<!----></a><br><br>As for the USSD codes, we do strip parts of the tel: links here [2]. More specifically, we call GURL::GetContent() which "is everything after the scheme (skipping the scheme delimiting colon) and before the fragment (skipping the fragment delimiting octothorpe)".<span class="line"><!---->As for the USSD codes, we do strip parts of the tel: links here [2]. More specifically, we call GURL::GetContent() which "is everything after the scheme (skipping the scheme delimiting colon) and before the fragment (skipping the fragment delimiting octothorpe)".<!----></span><br>Most (maybe all?) USSD codes have a '#' character in them, so they wouldn't be sent fully, is that enough to prevent bad actors?<span class="line"><!---->Most (maybe all?) USSD codes have a '#' character in them, so they wouldn't be sent fully, is that enough to prevent bad actors?<!----></span><br><br>[1]: <span class="line"><!---->[1]: <!----></span>https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:components/external_intents/android/java/src/org/chromium/components/external_intents/InterceptNavigationDelegateImpl.java;l=158;drc=f16cad21ac6fc30b080b57bfd77db7f61a9a8927<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:components/external_intents/android/java/src/org/chromium/components/external_intents/InterceptNavigationDelegateImpl.java;l=158;drc=f16cad21ac6fc30b080b57bfd77db7f61a9a8927"><!---->https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:components/external_intents/android/java/src/org/chromium/components/external_intents/InterceptNavigationDelegateImpl.java;l=158;drc=f16cad21ac6fc30b080b57bfd77db7f61a9a8927<!----></a><br>[2]: <span class="line"><!---->[2]: <!----></span>https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:chrome/browser/sharing/click_to_call/click_to_call_utils.cc;l=88;drc=f16cad21ac6fc30b080b57bfd77db7f61a9a8927<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:chrome/browser/sharing/click_to_call/click_to_call_utils.cc;l=88;drc=f16cad21ac6fc30b080b57bfd77db7f61a9a8927"><!---->https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:chrome/browser/sharing/click_to_call/click_to_call_utils.cc;l=88;drc=f16cad21ac6fc30b080b57bfd77db7f61a9a8927<!----></a><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

After seeing that issue, what comes to my mind is that, commonly web developers don't use `tel` in the iframe. If it was commonly used by developers, then it won't work in the Android devices because browsers safely block them while navigating. So, it would be a good idea if the team fixes the issue on the desktop too, yes?<span class="line"><!---->.           Comment 14<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1180510#c14">Comment 14<!----></a>

        Taken idea from my friend related to this. There is no reason to use `tel://` in an iframe. Because in the worst case, this would automatically dial the given phone number. It is, though, useful for links that have to be clicked. (One might argue, now, that you can initiate the click via XSS, but that's not the point, here ).<span class="line"><!---->Taken idea from my friend related to this. There is no reason to use `tel://` in an iframe. Because in the worst case, this would automatically dial the given phone number. It is, though, useful for links that have to be clicked. (One might argue, now, that you can initiate the click via XSS, but that's not the point, here ).<!----></span><br>Same for the lesser-known/-used phone:// pseudo-protocol or better yet: Only allow http:// and https://<span class="line"><!---->Same for the lesser-known/-used phone:// pseudo-protocol or better yet: Only allow http:// and https://<!----></span><br><br>In the past, some soft-phone/CAPI/TAPI solutions registered that protocol in addition to tel:// for automatically dialing the given number, when clicked.<span class="line"><!---->In the past, some soft-phone/CAPI/TAPI solutions registered that protocol in addition to tel:// for automatically dialing the given number, when clicked.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Sorry for the late response. I had another look at how we process tel links from clicking on a Desktop platform to receiving it on Android and noticed that we URL-decode the link twice.<span class="line"><!---->Sorry for the late response. I had another look at how we process tel links from clicking on a Desktop platform to receiving it on Android and noticed that we URL-decode the link twice.<!----></span><br>The first decoding happens here on the Desktop side: <span class="line"><!---->The first decoding happens here on the Desktop side: <!----></span>https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:chrome/browser/sharing/click_to_call/click_to_call_utils.cc;l=89;drc=0be726335b03670b246b23a41abbbfbd21b76a77<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:chrome/browser/sharing/click_to_call/click_to_call_utils.cc;l=89;drc=0be726335b03670b246b23a41abbbfbd21b76a77"><!---->https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:chrome/browser/sharing/click_to_call/click_to_call_utils.cc;l=89;drc=0be726335b03670b246b23a41abbbfbd21b76a77<!----></a><br>The second one here on the Android side: <span class="line"><!---->The second one here on the Android side: <!----></span>https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:chrome/android/java/src/org/chromium/chrome/browser/sharing/click_to_call/ClickToCallMessageHandler.java;l=119;drc=59d3a0d03d4da59f54dcf1a860e6c156d5be1354<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:chrome/android/java/src/org/chromium/chrome/browser/sharing/click_to_call/ClickToCallMessageHandler.java;l=119;drc=59d3a0d03d4da59f54dcf1a860e6c156d5be1354"><!---->https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:chrome/android/java/src/org/chromium/chrome/browser/sharing/click_to_call/ClickToCallMessageHandler.java;l=119;drc=59d3a0d03d4da59f54dcf1a860e6c156d5be1354<!----></a><br><br>The result of this is that clicking on the following link on Desktop and selecting a device via ClickToCall will open the IMEI device info page on Android (on Android N and below + O&P if the screen is on & unlocked immediately, other OS versions require an additional click on a notification on Android):<span class="line"><!---->The result of this is that clicking on the following link on Desktop and selecting a device via ClickToCall will open the IMEI device info page on Android (on Android N and below + O&amp;P if the screen is on &amp; unlocked immediately, other OS versions require an additional click on a notification on Android):<!----></span><br><a href="tel:*%252306%2523"><span class="line"><!---->&lt;a href="tel:*%252306%2523"&gt;<!----></span><br><br>The first "%25" here will be decoded to "%" (and won't be stripped by GURL::GetContent()). We then send the string "*%2306%23" to Android which decodes it again, now replacing "%23" with "#", resulting in an Intent for "tel:*#06#".<span class="line"><!---->The first "%25" here will be decoded to "%" (and won't be stripped by GURL::GetContent()). We then send the string "*%2306%23" to Android which decodes it again, now replacing "%23" with "#", resulting in an Intent for "tel:*#06#".<!----></span><br>Note that this is not different from a user on Android clicking on a link like this directly: <a href="tel:*%2306%23">. We still require the user to click on their device when they see the ClickToCall dialog on desktop.<span class="line"><!---->Note that this is not different from a user on Android clicking on a link like this directly: &lt;a href="tel:*%2306%23"&gt;. We still require the user to click on their device when they see the ClickToCall dialog on desktop.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">

        Respected Sir/Ma'am,<span class="line"><!---->Respected Sir/Ma'am,<!----></span><br><br>Good evening. No worries. Hope you're doing well on the side of the screen. Firstly, thank you very much for a crystal clear explanation. <span class="line"><!---->Good evening. No worries. Hope you're doing well on the side of the screen. Firstly, thank you very much for a crystal clear explanation. <!----></span><br><br>It isn't like that user will have to click "call" to perform but the tricky stuff over here is that Chrome Android Browser blocks from iframe but not Desktop. Now, talking about USSD attack, yes, in latest Android OS, it won't be possible directly but you know what, in earlier Android device if you sent any USSD code to dialer app, it will directly execute and the user isn't required to press "Call" like it is happening in last Android OS. If I am not wrong, the Android device you tested is surely Android 5.0 Lollipop or above or most probably it will be Marshmellow, Nougat or Oreo, yes? Did you try on older versions of Android and just adding some extra information that this was possible in past, Samsung and HTC device as I mentioned in my <span class="line"><!---->It isn't like that user will have to click "call" to perform but the tricky stuff over here is that Chrome Android Browser blocks from iframe but not Desktop. Now, talking about USSD attack, yes, in latest Android OS, it won't be possible directly but you know what, in earlier Android device if you sent any USSD code to dialer app, it will directly execute and the user isn't required to press "Call" like it is happening in last Android OS. If I am not wrong, the Android device you tested is surely Android 5.0 Lollipop or above or most probably it will be Marshmellow, Nougat or Oreo, yes? Did you try on older versions of Android and just adding some extra information that this was possible in past, Samsung and HTC device as I mentioned in my <!----></span>comment#11<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c11"><!---->comment#11<!----></a>, you can check about it here [1] <span class="line"><!---->, you can check about it here [1] <!----></span><br><br>Not only this much but as per [2], there was a Code execution using USSD attack and as per that blog it was done though webpages  so, it would be through browsers, yes? And Chrome is also our beloved Browser which has maximum Browser downloads on Play Store (telling as per the number of download). <span class="line"><!---->Not only this much but as per [2], there was a Code execution using USSD attack and as per that blog it was done though webpages  so, it would be through browsers, yes? And Chrome is also our beloved Browser which has maximum Browser downloads on Play Store (telling as per the number of download). <!----></span><br>What is stated in the blog:<span class="line"><!---->What is stated in the blog:<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>Further investigation revealed that redirects within web pages, either hard-coded or javascript, could also be used to push an arbitrary USSD code to the phone’s dialer. The feature being abused to trigger the reset is normally used to make placing phone calls easier while operating in the web browser. The disclosure shows that some unpatched devices could trigger the factory reset without human interaction.<span class="line"><!---->Further investigation revealed that redirects within web pages, either hard-coded or javascript, could also be used to push an arbitrary USSD code to the phone’s dialer. The feature being abused to trigger the reset is normally used to make placing phone calls easier while operating in the web browser. The disclosure shows that some unpatched devices could trigger the factory reset without human interaction.<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>It has also written that other browsers were vulnerable:<span class="line"><!---->It has also written that other browsers were vulnerable:<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>“The Unstructured Supplementary Service Data (USSD) code (which we won’t reproduce here) apparently only works on Samsung phones running Touchwiz, and only if you are directed to the dodgy destination while inside the stock browser (rather than Chrome, for example). “<span class="line"><!---->“The Unstructured Supplementary Service Data (USSD) code (which we won’t reproduce here) apparently only works on Samsung phones running Touchwiz, and only if you are directed to the dodgy destination while inside the stock browser (rather than Chrome, for example). “<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>There are few other browsers which are Chromium based and Samsung Internet is one of them and they are "pre-installed" in Samsung device. :) <span class="line"><!---->There are few other browsers which are Chromium based and Samsung Internet is one of them and they are "pre-installed" in Samsung device. :) <!----></span><br>As per [2], the impacts are:<span class="line"><!---->As per [2], the impacts are:<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>The full impact of this issue depends on the USSD codes available on a given device (i.e. what they do) and whether they execute automatically. These codes are not publicized by the carriers, although available in various forums online, and functions more damaging than factory reset might not exist. Regardless, the automatic execution of such codes is a vulnerability we will monitor and test further.<span class="line"><!---->The full impact of this issue depends on the USSD codes available on a given device (i.e. what they do) and whether they execute automatically. These codes are not publicized by the carriers, although available in various forums online, and functions more damaging than factory reset might not exist. Regardless, the automatic execution of such codes is a vulnerability we will monitor and test further.<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>Adding few other references just in case if you're curious to know how this was an issue in the past. :) <span class="line"><!---->Adding few other references just in case if you're curious to know how this was an issue in the past. :) <!----></span><br><br>As per [3], it can wipe complete devices and this looks something dangerous of matter of concern. <span class="line"><!---->As per [3], it can wipe complete devices and this looks something dangerous of matter of concern. <!----></span><br><br>Now, speaking of <span class="line"><!---->Now, speaking of <!----></span>comment#20<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c20"><!---->comment#20<!----></a> of @knollr sir/ma'am. <span class="line"><!----> of @knollr sir/ma'am. <!----></span><br>That's really tricky, yes? You might already be aware already but adding one more idea that there is not just one was to decode it let's say if somebody has encoded it in QR code and it is later decoded and performs USSD attack? If you're curious how this type of attack works, see [4] . So, we can say that there isn't always only one way to get answer 4, one can do 2+2 as well as 3+1 and maybe there will be other ways to exploit such issues? We aren't knowing, how it will be handled in the future maybe if there will be some faulty code with which such remote attack is chained, it will become a nightmare. Why don't we take precaution beforehand and anticipate about upcoming problems? Not only this much but also, there is "No Website", you will find sharing USSD code to be click, did you notice? They are in plain text because they are well aware it can be dangerous and the reader will get into problem. <span class="line"><!---->That's really tricky, yes? We then send the string "*%2306%23" to Android which decodes it again, now replacing "%23" with "#", resulting in an Intent for "tel:*#06#".<span class="line"><!---->&gt; The first "%25" here will be decoded to "%" (and won't be stripped by GURL::GetContent()). We then send the string "*%2306%23" to Android which decodes it again, now replacing "%23" with "#", resulting in an Intent for "tel:*#06#".<!----></span><br>Note that this is not different from a user on Android clicking on a link like this directly: <a href="tel:*%2306%23">. We still require the user to click on their device when they see the ClickToCall dialog on desktop.<!----></span><br><br>Absolutely correct.         Thanks for the additional information!<span class="line"><!---->Thanks for the additional information!<!----></span><br><br>To summarize, I'd suggest the following next steps for this particular bug:<span class="line"><!---->To summarize, I'd suggest the following next steps for this particular bug:<!----></span><br>1) Fix the double url-decoding I found and mentioned in <span class="line"><!---->1) Fix the double url-decoding I found and mentioned in <!----></span>#c20<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c20"><!---->#c20<!----></a> by always sending url-encoded numbers from Desktop<span class="line"><!----> by always sending url-encoded numbers from Desktop<!----></span><br>    Alternatively keep the decoded number on Desktop but don't decode again on Android.<span class="line"><!---->    Alternatively keep the decoded number on Desktop but don't decode again on Android.<!----></span><br>2) Ignore received numbers that contain "*" or "#" after url-decoding on Android (we already stripped everything after "#" but that didn't work because of <span class="line"><!---->2) Ignore received numbers that contain "*" or "#" after url-decoding on or custom builds.<!----></span><br>3) Don't offer Click to Call devices on Desktop for numbers that would fail the validation in 2)<span class="line"><!---->3) Don't offer Click to Call devices on Desktop for numbers that would fail the validation in 2)<!----></span><br>    Optional step but makes it clear that these numbers won't work with Click to Call.<span class="line"><!---->    Optional step but makes it clear that these numbers won't work with Click to Call.<!----></span><br><br>I consider the iframe specific parts of this bug as out of scope given that we already have <span         Can you please mention the reason how come it will be out of scope? Because you can transfer the Balance from one device to another directly just by sending USSD code and can perform steps like enabling and disabling functions. If this issue was limited to Restart, it can be DoS and yes then you can count it Out of scope. But as far as I can tell, it can also "reset" users device using the steps I mentioned in my previous comments. I hope that this isn't limited to restart which is DoS but wiping a user's device from Chrome browser is something which should be qualified, yes? Thanks in advance. :)<span class="line"><!---->Can you please mention the reason how come it will be out of scope? Because you can transfer the Balance from one device to another directly just by sending USSD code and can perform steps like enabling and disabling functions. If this issue was limited to Restart, it can be DoS and yes then you can count it Out of scope. But as far as I can tell, it can also "reset" users device using the steps I mentioned in my previous comments. I hope that this isn't limited to restart which is DoS but wiping a user's device from Chrome browser is something which should be qualified, yes? Thanks in advance. :)<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

    <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>

          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1180510#c26">Comment 26<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>

        <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Apr 6, 2021, 9:34 AM EDT"></chops-timestamp>

        The out of scope part is to do special handling for iframes on Desktop. The current difference we have is that navigating an iframe on Android to an external protocol will be ignored, while on Desktop we will forward them to apps or, for tel: links, offer Click to Call. This is confusing to users as the number is not initiated from the top level origin which is why we show the iframe origin in the Click to Call dialog in those cases.<span class="line"><!---->The out of scope part is to do special handling for iframes on Desktop. The current difference we have is that navigating an iframe on Android to an external protocol will be ignored, while on Desktop we will forward them to apps or, for tel: links, offer Click to Call. This is confusing to users as the number is not initiated from the top level origin which is why we show the iframe origin in the Click to Call dialog in those cases.<!----></span><br><br>My reasoning for making this out of scope is that we already have <span class="line"><!---->My reasoning for making this out of scope is that we already have <!----></span>crbug.com/1011429<a class="" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1011429" title="Add metrics for deprecating non-understandable external protocol requests"><!---->crbug.com/1011429<!----></a> that will look into iframe navigations to external protocols *and* USSD codes won't be able to be sent at all, including iframes, after the steps outlined in <span class="line"><!----> that will look into iframe navigations to external protocols *and* USSD codes won't be able to be sent at all, including iframes, after the steps outlined in <!----></span>#c24<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c24"><!---->#c24<!----></a> are implemented.<span class="line"><!----> are implemented.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        The following revision refers to this bug:<span class="line"><!---->The following revision refers to this bug:<!----></span><br>  <span class="line"><!---->  <!----></span>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/e041be8dc8b5b9e3012e752c2636fcf1cd8b0b1d<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/e041be8dc8b5b9e3012e752c2636fcf1cd8b0b1d"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/e041be8dc8b5b9e3012e752c2636fcf1cd8b0b1d<!----></a><br><br>commit <span class="line"><!---->commit <!----></span>e041be8dc8b5b9e3012e752c2636fcf1cd8b0b1d<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://crrev.com/e041be8dc8b5b9e3012e752c2636fcf1cd8b0b1d"><!---->e041be8dc8b5b9e3012e752c2636fcf1cd8b0b1d<!----></a><br>Author: Richard Knoll <<span class="line"><!---->Author: Richard Knoll &lt;<!----></span>knollr@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="/u/knollr@chromium.org"><!---->knollr@chromium.org<!----></a>><span class="line"><!---->&gt;<!----></span><br>Date: Fri Apr 23 08:56:16 2021<span class="line"><!---->Date: Fri Apr 23 08:56:16 2021<!----></span><br><br>Prevent USSD codes via Click to Call<span class="line"><!---->Prevent USSD codes via Click to Call<!----></span><br><br>Click to Call allows users to send a phone number from their Chrome<span class="line"><!---->Click to Call allows users to send a phone number from their Chrome<!----></span><br>desktop instance to their Android phone. This number either comes from a<span class="line"><!---->desktop instance to their Android phone. This number either comes from a<!----></span><br>user's selection and sent via the context menu, or by clicking on a link<span class="line"><!---->user's selection and sent via the context menu, or by clicking on a link<!----></span><br>with a "tel:" href.<span class="line"><!---->with a "tel:" href.<!----></span><br>Sending from the context menu is gated by a regular expression and will<span class="line"><!---->Sending from the context menu is gated by a regular expression and will<!----></span><br>not allow any special characters like '#' or '*' to be contained in the<span class="line"><!---->not allow any special characters like '#' or '*' to be contained in the<!----></span><br>phone number.<span class="line"><!---->phone number.<!----></span><br>Sending link hrefs does not go through that check as we assume the link<span class="line"><!---->Sending link hrefs does not go through that check as we assume the link<!----></span><br>is a valid phone number. We do call GURL::GetContent() to get the number<span class="line"><!---->is a valid phone number. We do call GURL::GetContent() to get the number<!----></span><br>which should discard anything after a (and including the) '#' character.<span class="line"><!---->which should discard anything after a (and including the) '#' character.<!----></span><br>However, we also URL-decoded the resulting string before then sending it<span class="line"><!---->However, we also URL-decoded the resulting string before then sending it<!----></span><br>over to Android, where we URL-decoded it again when constructing the<span class="line"><!---->over to Android, where we URL-decoded it again when constructing the<!----></span><br>Dialer intent. This allows sending double-URL-encoded USSD tel links<span class="line"><!---->Dialer intent. This allows sending double-URL-encoded USSD tel links<!----></span><br>which will be sent straight to the Dialer on certain Android versions<span class="line"><!---->which will be sent straight to the Dialer on certain Android versions<!----></span><br>and device states.<span class="line"><!---->and device states.<!----></span><br><br>The fix here is on both desktop and Android side:<span class="line"><!---->The fix here is on both desktop and Android side:<!----></span><br>Desktop:<span class="line"><!---->Desktop:<!----></span><br> - URL-decode the number and ignore if it contains '#', '*' or '%'.<span class="line"><!----> - URL-decode the number and ignore if it contains '#', '*' or '%'.<!----></span><br> - Send the raw number (URL-encoded) to Android<span class="line"><!----> - Send the raw number (URL-encoded) to Android<!----></span><br>Android:<span class="line"><!---->Android:<!----></span><br> - Verify that URL-decoding the received raw number is valid as above<span class="line"><!----> - Verify that URL-decoding the received raw number is valid as above<!----></span><br> - Show the decoded number in the notification<span class="line"><!----> - Show the decoded number in the notification<!----></span><br> - Parse the raw number in Java into a Uri object for the Dialer<span class="line"><!----> - Parse the raw number in Java into a Uri object for the Dialer<!----></span><br><br>Together this makes sure that we only URL-decode tel: links once and<span class="line"><!---->Together this makes sure that we only URL-decode tel: links once and<!----></span><br>verify it on both sender and receiver side before passing it on to the<span class="line"><!---->verify it on both sender and receiver side before passing it on to the<!----></span><br>Android Dialer.<span class="line"><!---->Android Dialer.<!----></span><br><br>Bug: 1180510<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1180510" title="security: click-to-call across devices has inconsistent escaping &amp; URL validation"><!---->Bug: 1180510<!----></a><br>Test: updated unit_tests and browser_tests to check for conversion<span         *** Boilerplate reminders! ***<span class="line"><!---->*** Boilerplate reminders! ***<!----></span><br>Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<span class="line"><!---->Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<!----></span><br><br>Please contact <span class="line"><!---->Please contact <!----></span>security-vrp@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="mailto:security-vrp@chromium.org"><!---->security-vrp@chromium.org<!----></a> with any questions.<span class="line"><!----> with any questions.<!----></span><br>******************************<span class="line"><!---->******************************<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Hello,<span class="line"><!---->Hello,<!----></span><br>Good afternoon. <span class="line"><!---->Good afternoon. <!----></span><br>RE <span class="line"><!---->RE <!----></span>comment#48<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c48"><!---->comment#48<!----></a>: Thank you @amy ma'am. :)<span class="line"><!---->: Thank you @amy ma'am. :)<!----></span><br><br>I am currently not sure about this. But @knollr is it possible to check this case as well? We've got one more URI like `tel:` which is `callto:`. I was trying to go more deeper for the `tel:` URI in the RFC5341 at [1]. While going through that, something which clicked to me was about Skype which also has ability to call and as Skype uses URI like `callto:`, if we use that URI with the USSD code, it will directly be called, PTAL at [2]. Currently, I haven't tried to check if this will be possible to use. Like if we use USSD code and if the user has selected Skype as application which should be used then it might be problem. <span class="line"><!---->I am currently not sure about this. But @knollr is it possible to check this case as well? We've got one more URI like `tel:` which is `callto:`. I was trying to go more deeper for the `tel:` URI in the RFC5341 at [1]. While going through that, something which clicked to me was about Skype which also has ability to call and as Skype uses URI like `callto:`, if we use that URI with the USSD code, it will directly be called, PTAL at [2]. Currently, I haven't tried to check if this will be possible to use. Like if we use USSD code and if the user has selected Skype as application which should be used then it might be problem. <!----></span><br><br>And is it really possible to use phone number without prefix `tel:`? Maybe check [3].<span class="line"><!---->And is it really possible to use phone number without prefix `tel:`? Maybe check [3].<!----></span><br><br>Viber also has a URI  like `viber://` it also has calling function but have never seen a real life example where it will be possible to make a call. Like for whatsapp too we have ability to send a text and that too the test will be added in the text box but won't be sent until user clicks `>`/Send. So, yes, application like this who have calling function won't be affected from it and as Chrome would be stripping it out on their behalf for `tel:` URI, there won't be issue.<span class="line"><!---->Viber also has a URI  like `viber://` it also has calling function but have never seen a real life example where it will be possible to make a call. Like for whatsapp too we have ability to send a text and that too the test will be added in the text box but won't be sent until user clicks `&gt;`/Send. So, yes, application like this who have calling function won't be affected from it and as Chrome would be stripping it out on their behalf for `tel:` URI, there won't be issue.<!----></span><br><br>Will `callto:` have similar issue? The protection is well implemented by the team for `tel:` URI as the `%` itself is blocked so, everything is in good hands and there is no bypass. :P But would be happy if one can check for this `callto:` functionality. Does this work? I don't have skype on my device but maybe try with this:<span class="line"><!---->Will `callto:` have similar issue? The protection is well implemented by the team for `tel:` URI as the `%` itself is blocked so, everything is in good hands and there is no bypass. :P But would be happy if one can check for this `callto:` functionality. Does this work? I don't have skype on my device but maybe try with this:<!----></span><br><br>data:text/html,<a href="callto:*%2306%23">click</a><span class="line"><!---->data:text/html,&lt;a href="callto:*%2306%23"&gt;click&lt;/a&gt;<!----></span><br><br>When I use that URI in the Chrome stable (OS: Android), it says about:blank#blocked, looks like to be good but no idea why it has different behavior in the Desktop. I don't have one iOS device on my hand. So, I don't know what is behavior on it. But most probably iOS will have same behavior as Android.<span class="line"><!---->When I use that URI in the Chrome stable (OS: Android), it says about:blank#blocked, looks like to be good but no idea why it has different behavior in the Desktop. I don't have one iOS device on my hand. So, I don't know what is behavior on it. But most probably iOS will have same behavior as Android.<!----></span><br><br><br>[1]: <span class="line"><!---->[1]: <!----></span>https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc5341<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc5341"><!---->https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc5341<!----></a><br>[2]: <span class="line"><!---->[2]: <!----></span>https://stackoverflow.com/questions/20132663/sending-ussd-code-programmatically-dials-skype-instead-of-normal-phone-call<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/20132663/sending-ussd-code-programmatically-dials-skype-instead-of-normal-phone-call"><!---->https://stackoverflow.com/questions/20132663/sending-ussd-code-programmatically-dials-skype-instead-of-normal-phone-call<!----></a><br>[3]: <span class="line"><!---->[3]: <!----></span>https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Property:P1329<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Property:P1329"><!---->https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Property:P1329<!----></a><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Click to Call (the feature that sends a number from desktop > phone) is only shown for tel: links [1] and won't show for callto: or other external protocols.<span class="line"><!---->Click to Call (the feature that sends a number from desktop &gt; phone) is only shown for tel: links [1] and won't show for callto: or other external protocols.<!----></span><br>If you find an issue with those links (callto, viber, etc) feel free to open a new bug with the repro steps but it'll likely not affect Click to Call.<span class="line"><!---->If you find an issue with those links (callto, viber, etc) feel free to open a new bug with the repro steps but it'll likely not affect Click to Call.<!----></span><br><br>[1]: <span class="line"><!---->[1]: <!----></span>https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:chrome/browser/sharing/click_to_call/click_to_call_utils.cc;l=82;drc=9fcc9d7b2915b6192ee6810eec54c50deb6313c6<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:chrome/browser/sharing/click_to_call/click_to_call_utils.cc;l=82;drc=9fcc9d7b2915b6192ee6810eec54c50deb6313c6"><!---->https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:chrome/browser/sharing/click_to_call/click_to_call_utils.cc;l=82;drc=9fcc9d7b2915b6192ee6810eec54c50deb6313c6<!----></a><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          Comment 58<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1180510#c58">Comment 58<!----></a>

link for instructions on filing security bugs:<!----></b><br>https://www.chromium.org/Home/chromium-security/reporting-security-bugs<b class="line"><!---->https://www.chromium.org/Home/chromium-security/reporting-security-bugs<!----></b><br><br>Reports may be eligible for reward payments under the Chrome VRP:<b class="line"><!---->Reports may be eligible for reward payments under the Chrome VRP:<!----></b><br>http://g.co/ChromeBugRewards<b class="line"><!---->http://g.co/ChromeBugRewards<!----></b><br><br>NOTE: Security bugs are normally made public once a fix has been widely<b class="line"><!---->NOTE: Security bugs are normally made public once a fix has been widely<!----></b><br>deployed.<b class="line"><!---->deployed.<!----></b><br><br>-------------------------<b class="line"><!---->-------------------------<!----></b><br><br>VULNERABILITY DETAILS<b class="line"><!---->VULNERABILITY DETAILS<!----></b><br>Please provide a brief explanation of the security issue.<b class="line"><!---->Please provide a brief explanation of the security issue.<!----></b><br><br>VERSION<b class="line"><!---->VERSION<!----></b><br>Chrome Version: 88.0.4324.150 (Official Build) (64-bit) (cohort: Stable)<span class="line"><!---->Chrome Version: 88.0.4324.150 (Official Build) (64-bit) (cohort: Stable)<!----></span><br>Operating System: Windows 10 OS Version 1909 (Build 18363.1379)<span class="line"><!---->Operating System: Windows 10 OS Version 1909 (Build 18363.1379)<!----></span><br><br>REPRODUCTION CASE<b class="line"><!---->REPRODUCTION CASE<!----></b><br>Please include a demonstration of the security bug, such as an attached<b class="line"><!---->Please include a demonstration of the security bug, such as an attached<!----></b><br>HTML or binary file that reproduces the bug when loaded in Chrome. PLEASE<b class="line"><!---->HTML or binary file that reproduces the bug when loaded in Chrome. PLEASE<!----></b><br>make the file as small as possible and remove any content not required to<b class="line"><!---->make the file as small as possible and remove any content not required to<!----></b><br>demonstrate the bug, or any personal or confidential information.<b class="line"><!---->demonstrate the bug, or any personal or confidential information.<!----></b><br><br>Please attach files directly, not in zip or other archive formats, and if<b class="line"><!---->Please attach files directly, not in zip or other archive formats, and if<!----></b><br>you've created a demonstration site please also attach the files needed to<b class="line"><!---->you've created a demonstration site please also attach the files needed to<!----></b><br>reproduce the demonstration locally.<b class="line"><!---->reproduce the demonstration locally.<!----></b><br><br>FOR CRASHES, PLEASE INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING ADDITIONAL INFORMATION<b class="line"><!---->FOR CRASHES, PLEASE INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING ADDITIONAL INFORMATION<!----></b><br>Type of crash: [tab, browser, etc.]<b class="line"><!---->Type of crash: [tab, browser, etc.]<!----></b><br>Crash State: [see link above: stack trace *with symbols*, registers,<b class="line"><!---->Crash State: [see link above: stack trace *with symbols*, registers,<!----></b><br>exception record]<b class="line"><!---->exception record]<!----></b><br>Client ID (if relevant): [see link above]<b class="line"><!---->Client ID (if relevant): [see link above]<!----></b><br><br>CREDIT INFORMATION<b class="line"><!---->CREDIT INFORMATION<!----></b><br>Externally reported security bugs may appear in Chrome release notes.         Respected Sir/Ma'am,<span class="line"><!---->Respected Sir/Ma'am,<!----></span><br><br>Good evening. Hope you're doing well. Okay, yes, let's talk about the issue. I will bisect the report into few parts for better understanding.<span class="line"><!---->Good evening. Hope you're doing well. Okay, yes, let's talk about the issue. I will bisect the report into few parts for better understanding.<!----></span><br><br>1. As far as I know, browsers have a security implementation that one can't use "tel:" in the iframes means it won't open Phone Dialer app. Let's see a proof?<span class="line"><!---->1. As far as I know, browsers have a security implementation that one can't use "tel:" in the iframes means it won't open Phone Dialer app. Let's see a proof?<!----></span><br>--> Enter this into the address bar: data:text/html,<iframe src='tel:+91123456789'><span class="line"><!---->--&gt; Enter this into the address bar: data:text/html,&lt;iframe src='tel:+91123456789'&gt;<!----></span><br>Observations on 2 different Operating Systems:<span class="line"><!---->Observations on 2 different Operating Systems:<!----></span><br><br>Chrome Android (Dev | Version: 90.0.4413.0 | Android 9.0): It doesn't open Dialer app in the Android Browser.<span class="line"><!---->Chrome Android (Dev | Version: 90.0.4413.0 | Android 9.0): It doesn't open Dialer app in the Android Browser.<!----></span><br>Reason: I am not sure for the reason but it maybe because the one can't open applications from iframe using URIs like tel: mailto: etc?<span class="line"><!---->Reason: I am not sure for the reason but it maybe because the one can't open applications from iframe using URIs like tel: mailto: etc?<!----></span><br><br>Chrome Windows (Stable | Version: 88.0.4324.150 | Windows 10 x64): It will give a prompt like something where you can select a device where the same Gmail is logged in as Chrome (desktop) and once you'll click it, it will open the Dialer Android App. <span class="line"><!---->Chrome Windows (Stable | Version: 88.0.4324.150 | Windows 10 x64): It will give a prompt like something where you can select a device where the same Gmail is logged in as Chrome (desktop) and once you'll click it, it will open the Dialer Android App. <!----></span><br>Reason: The Browser allowed tel URI from iframe which shouldn't be allowed.<span class="line"><!---->Reason: The Browser allowed tel URI from iframe which shouldn't be allowed.<!----></span><br><br>Let's go to next step. As per @rbyers. there can be issues like Factory data reset etc can take place in some Android devices. I have kept a PoC where there is tel: with a '*' in it and it wasn't stripped out by the Browser when sent to the Dialer app of Android device. <span class="line"><!---->Let's go to next step. As per @rbyers. there can be issues like Factory data reset etc can take place in some Android devices. I have kept a PoC where there is tel: with a '*' in it and it wasn't stripped out by the Browser when sent to the Dialer app of Android device. <!----></span><br><br>2. Few Browsers who are Chromium based aren't checking the characters after '*' and completely transferred the USSD code to the Dialer Application which maybe a huge concern for them. What kind of security check Chrome has implemented to protect against such issues, can you please share a link to that specific security check or feature? Thanks in advance. :) <span class="line"><!---->2. Few Browsers who are Chromium based aren't checking the characters after '*' and completely transferred the USSD code to the Dialer Application which maybe a huge concern for them. What kind of security check Chrome has implemented to protect against such issues, can you please share a link to that specific security check or feature? Thanks in advance. :) <!----></span><br><br>I will conclude here and tell that Chrome (desktop) is allowing tel: in the Iframe which shouldn't be done and which can be a huge security concern in older Android devices. I am not sure but this is also an issue in the Android device when it takes any digits on the dialer app without checking? If it is, what kind of check do Android OS have to protect users from it? I am always eager to learn something new from Chromium Security Team as they have got one of the best Browser team all over the World. Thanks in advance. Take care!<span class="line"><!---->I will conclude here and tell that Chrome (desktop) is allowing tel: in the Iframe which shouldn't be done and which can be a huge security concern in older Android devices. I am not sure but this is also an issue in the Android device when it takes any digits on the dialer app without checking? If it is, what kind of check do Android OS have to protect users from it? I am always eager to learn something new from Chromium Security Team as they have got one of the best Browser team all over the World. Thanks in advance. Take care!<!----></span><br><br>Kind Regards,<span class="line"><!---->Kind Regards,<!----></span><br>Kirtikumar A. R.<span class="line"><!---->Kirtikumar A. R.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Thanks for your report. I think what you're saying is that there are two possible bugs that intertwine interestingly:<span class="line"><!---->Thanks for your report. I think what you're saying is that there are two possible bugs that intertwine interestingly:<!----></span><br> 1. Desktop users can click a tel: link in an iframe. On Chrome, you can then send that number to a mobile Chrome, which then passes it to the dialer.<span class="line"><!----> 1. Desktop users can click a tel: link in an iframe. On Chrome, you can then send that number to a mobile Chrome, which then passes it to the dialer.<!----></span><br> 2. Since Chrome doesn't strip # and * from the number, someone could do something nefarious.<span class="line"><!----> 2. Since Chrome doesn't strip # and * from the number, someone could do something nefarious.<!----></span><br><br>As you noted, the second one is a known issue (<span class="line"><!---->As you noted, the second one is a known issue (<!----></span>crbug.com/746427<a class="" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=746427" title="Are some tel: links a security issue on Android?"><!---->crbug.com/746427<!----></a>). I don't know whether the lack of iframe tel support on Android is intentional or not, but it does seem plausible that we should share the behavior.<span class="line"><!---->). I don't know whether the lack of iframe tel support on Android is intentional or not, but it does seem plausible that we should share the behavior.<!----></span><br><br>mkwst@/qinmin@: do you know if the iframe tel mitigation is intentional and/or based on some spec? Ought the desktop/Android behavior be unified?<span class="line"><!---->mkwst@/qinmin@: do you know if the iframe tel mitigation is intentional and/or based on some spec? Ought the desktop/Android behavior be unified?<!----></span><br><br>I'm keeping this as a security bug for now, albeit Severity-Low, out of an abundance of caution. Fixing the iframe limitation would only be a fairly minimal abuse mitigation for the <span class="line"><!---->I'm keeping this as a security bug for now, albeit Severity-Low, out of an abundance of caution. Fixing the iframe limitation would only be a fairly minimal abuse mitigation for the <!----></span>crbug.com/746427<a class="" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=746427" title="Are some tel: links a security issue on Android?"><!---->crbug.com/746427<!----></a> issue, but whether or not unadorned iframes should have that privilege still seems like an OWP security question.<span class="line"><!----> issue, but whether or not unadorned iframes should have that privilege still seems like an OWP security question.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        The relevant specs are quite vague on navigation to non-webby schemes. The switch in step 15 of <span class="line"><!---->The relevant specs are quite vague on navigation to non-webby schemes. The switch in step 15 of <!----></span>https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/browsing-the-web.html#navigate<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/browsing-the-web.html#navigate"><!---->https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/browsing-the-web.html#navigate<!----></a> takes you to <span class="line"><!----> takes you to <!----></span>https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/browsing-the-web.html#process-a-navigate-url-scheme<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/browsing-the-web.html#process-a-navigate-url-scheme"><!---->https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/browsing-the-web.html#process-a-navigate-url-scheme<!----></a>,<span class="line"><!---->,<!----></span> and then to <span class="line"><!----> and then to <!----></span>https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/browsing-the-web.html#hand-off-to-external-software<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/browsing-the-web.html#hand-off-to-external-software"><!---->https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/browsing-the-web.html#hand-off-to-external-software<!----></a>,<span class="line"><!---->,<!----></span> which waves its hands in the direction of a risk to be mitigated, but has little concrete advice about doing so.<span class="line"><!----> which waves its hands in the direction of a risk to be mitigated, but has little concrete advice about doing so.<!----></span><br><br>I don't know of an intentional handling of `tel` for framed navigation, but I agree that we should be consistent across desktop and mobile. Skimming through the codebase for instances of `kTelScheme`, we have a few features which special-case it in some way (<span class="line"><!---->I don't know of an intentional handling of `tel` for framed navigation, but I agree that we should be consistent across desktop and mobile. Skimming through the codebase for instances of `kTelScheme`, we have a few features which special-case it in some way (<!----></span>https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:chrome/browser/chromeos/external_protocol_dialog.cc;drc=f16cad21ac6fc30b080b57bfd77db7f61a9a8927;l=119<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:chrome/browser/chromeos/external_protocol_dialog.cc;drc=f16cad21ac6fc30b080b57bfd77db7f61a9a8927;l=119"><!---->https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:chrome/browser/chromeos/external_protocol_dialog.cc;drc=f16cad21ac6fc30b080b57bfd77db7f61a9a8927;l=119<!----></a>,<span         A few observations here :-)<span class="line"><!---->A few observations here :-)<!----></span><br>On Android we do seem to block navigations to external protocols here [1]. They fail with a "Navigation is blocked: tel:+xxx" log message in the JS console.<span class="line"><!---->On Android we do seem to block navigations to external protocols here [1]. They fail with a "Navigation is blocked: tel:+xxx" log message in the JS console.<!----></span><br>That doesn't prevent the user from clicking on tel: links though, even if the link itself is in an iframe. Relevant bug: <span class="line"><!---->That doesn't prevent the user from clicking on tel: links though, even if the link itself is in an iframe. Relevant bug: <!----></span>crbug.com/594996<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://crbug.com/594996"><!---->crbug.com/594996<!----></a><br>For desktop there is an open bug to limit external protocol navigations here: <span class="line"><!---->For desktop there is an open bug to limit external protocol navigations here: <!----></span>crbug.com/1011429<a class="" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1011429" title="Add metrics for deprecating non-understandable external protocol requests"><!---->crbug.com/1011429<!----></a><br><br>As for the USSD codes, we do strip parts of the tel: links here [2]. More specifically, we call GURL::GetContent() which "is everything after the scheme (skipping the scheme delimiting colon) and before the fragment (skipping the fragment delimiting octothorpe)".<span class="line"><!---->As for the USSD codes, we do strip parts of the tel: links here [2]. More specifically, we call GURL::GetContent() which "is everything after the scheme (skipping the scheme delimiting colon) and before the fragment (skipping the fragment delimiting octothorpe)".<!----></span><br>Most (maybe all?) USSD codes have a '#' character in them, so they wouldn't be sent fully, is that enough to prevent bad actors?<span class="line"><!---->Most (maybe all?) USSD codes have a '#' character in them, so they wouldn't be sent fully, is that enough to prevent bad actors?<!----></span><br><br>[1]: <span class="line"><!---->[1]: <!----></span>https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:components/external_intents/android/java/src/org/chromium/components/external_intents/InterceptNavigationDelegateImpl.java;l=158;drc=f16cad21ac6fc30b080b57bfd77db7f61a9a8927<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:components/external_intents/android/java/src/org/chromium/components/external_intents/InterceptNavigationDelegateImpl.java;l=158;drc=f16cad21ac6fc30b080b57bfd77db7f61a9a8927"><!---->https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:components/external_intents/android/java/src/org/chromium/components/external_intents/InterceptNavigationDelegateImpl.java;l=158;drc=f16cad21ac6fc30b080b57bfd77db7f61a9a8927<!----></a><br>[2]: <span class="line"><!---->[2]: <!----></span>https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:chrome/browser/sharing/click_to_call/click_to_call_utils.cc;l=88;drc=f16cad21ac6fc30b080b57bfd77db7f61a9a8927<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:chrome/browser/sharing/click_to_call/click_to_call_utils.cc;l=88;drc=f16cad21ac6fc30b080b57bfd77db7f61a9a8927"><!---->https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:chrome/browser/sharing/click_to_call/click_to_call_utils.cc;l=88;drc=f16cad21ac6fc30b080b57bfd77db7f61a9a8927<!----></a><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        > But it might be possible on Samsung or HTC users (Similar USSD issue was in past).<span class="line"><!---->&gt; But it might be possible on Samsung or HTC users (Similar USSD issue was in past).<!----></span><br>Note that removing of the # character and the following ones is done on the Desktop side before sending it down to Android already. So this is independent of the mobile device brand.<span class="line"><!---->Note that removing of the # character and the following ones is done on the Desktop side before sending it down to Android already. So this is independent of the mobile device brand.<!----></span><br><br>> why the Chrome desktop didn't block the navigation to Dialer from an iframe?<span class="line"><!---->&gt; why the Chrome desktop didn't block the navigation to Dialer from an iframe?<!----></span><br>That's what <span class="line"><!---->That's what <!----></span>crbug.com/1011429<a class="" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1011429" title="Add metrics for deprecating non-understandable external protocol requests"><!---->crbug.com/1011429<!----></a> is about, understanding if we can add the same restriction we have on Android to Desktop. There might be some valid use-cases like call centers that might need behaviour like that so we need to be certain it doesn't break them.<span class="line"><!----> is about, understanding if we can add the same restriction we have on Android to Desktop. There might be some valid use-cases like call centers that might need behaviour like that so we need to be certain it doesn't break them.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        > Note that removing of the # character and the following ones is done on the Desktop side before sending it down to Android already. After seeing that issue, what comes to my mind is that, commonly web developers don't use `tel` in the iframe. If it was commonly used by developers, then it won't work in the Android devices because browsers safely block them while navigating.         Taken idea from my friend related to this. There is no reason to use `tel://` in an iframe. Because in the worst case, this would automatically dial the given phone number. It is, though, useful for links that have to be clicked. (One might argue, now, that you can initiate the click via XSS, but that's not the point, here ).<span class="line"><!---->Taken idea from my friend related to this. There is no reason to use `tel://` in an iframe. Because in the worst case, this would automatically dial the given phone number. It is, though, useful for links that have to be clicked. (One might argue, now, that you can initiate the click via XSS, but that's not the point, here ).<!----></span><br>Same for the lesser-known/-used phone:// pseudo-protocol or better yet: Only allow http:// and https://<span class="line"><!---->Same for the lesser-known/-used phone:// pseudo-protocol or better yet: Only allow http:// and https://<!----></span><br><br>In the past, some soft-phone/CAPI/TAPI solutions registered that protocol in addition to tel:// for automatically dialing the given number, when clicked.<span class="line"><!---->In the past, some soft-phone/CAPI/TAPI solutions registered that protocol in addition to tel:// for automatically dialing the given number, when clicked.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1180510#c20">Comment 20<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
